awd_titl_txt: Evolutionary and Developmental Mechanisms of Embryo Dormancy in Rice
awd_abstract_narration:
Name: Xing-You Gu
Proposal number: IOS-1021382
Title of the proposal: Evolutionary and developmental mechanisms of embryo dormancy in rice 

Domestication of cereal crops from wild relatives has reduced seed dormancy, which can be imposed by inherent constraints within the embryo (embryo dormancy) or by restrictive tissues covering the embryo (coat-imposed dormancy). A small region of the genome designated as qSD12 has been isolated from weedy rice and is known to contain one or more genes that control embryo dormancy. Map-based cloning has identified two candidate genes for qSD12. The project aims to determine the function, origin, differentiation, and distribution of the candidates and to identify qSD12 downstream gene networks that regulate the development of embryo dormancy in the rice model system. Isogenic lines for the candidate genes and several approaches, such as complementation, haplotype, and transcriptomic analyses, will be used to achieve these objectives. The project is expected to assign one or two of the candidate genes to the function of embryo dormancy, reveal whether the dormancy gene(s) differentiated before or after the rice domestication, whether cultivated rice species and subspecies originated from different functional mutations, and provide direct knowledge of molecular and physiological pathways through which the naturally occurring gene regulates embryo dormancy. The broader impacts of the project include: 1) practical training for graduate, undergraduate, and high school students and teachers in biology and agricultural programs; and 2) interdisciplinary collaborations to use the dormancy gene for breeding varieties resistant to pre-harvest sprouting and to test the hypothesis that orthologous genes regulate dormancy and germination in other grasses.

Seed dormancy is the arrested status of a morphologically developed embryo, which is acquired primarily on the mother plant to delay germination after maturation. The dormancy trait is of both ecological and agricultural importance, as it promotes the survival of wild species in adverse environments, contributes to the persistence of weed and invasive plants in crop and range lands, and also provides cereal crops with resistance to pre-harvest sprouting (PHS). Despite years of research in seed biology, little is known how the growth of the embryo enclosed in a mature seed is arrested to maintain the dormant state. The goal of this project is to elucidate genetic, physiological, evolutionary, and molecular mechanisms regulating the development of seed dormancy in grasses (Poaceae), ultimately to provide basic knowledge and novel genes to develop new weed management strategies and to improve the resistance of cereal crops to PHS.

In the previous research, a set of quantitative trait loci for seed dormancy, including qSD1-2 and qSD12, was identified in weedy and cultivated rice (Oryza sativa). In this research, a total of four genes were cloned from qSD1-2 and qSD12 and characterized for their regulatory roles in the development of primary dormancy.

qSD1-2 was associated specifically with endosperm-imposed dormancy and cloned as a gibberellin (GA) synthesis gene (OsGa20ox2), which is identical to the “Green Revolution” gene semidwadf1. Expression of OsGa20ox2 in early developing seeds increased the accumulation of the GA hormone, which in turn promoted the morphogenesis of seed component tissues and subsequent maturation programs. Whereas, loss-of-function mutations of OsGa20ox2 reduced the GA content at the early stage, which decelerated the tissue morphogenesis including endosperm cell differentiation, delayed the accumulation of the dormancy-inducing hormone abscisic acid, and postponed dehydration, physiological maturity, and acquisition of germination ability. As the endosperm of developing seeds dominates moisture equilibrium and desiccation status of the embryo in cereal crops, qSD1-2 is believed to control primary dormancy through a GA-regulated dehydration mechanism. In addition, the same molecular identify of qSD1-2 and semidwarf1 clearly demonstrates that the “Green Revolution” characterized by use of semidwarf genes to lower plant height in cereal crop breeding in the past >50 years has contributed, to some extent, to the PHS resistance in crop production.      

qSD12 was associated specifically with embryo dormancy and has been reported to have the largest effect on germination in wild, weedy or cultivated rice. Map-based cloning of qSD12 identified three functionally differentiated genes, each having an additive effect on seed dormancy. Two or all of the three genes acted cumulatively to show a major effect. Two of the three genes encode predicted bHLH family transcription factors and the other encodes a hypothetic protein unknown for molecular function. These genes were all transcribed at the highest level in the embryo of developing seeds, where they regulated expressions of downstream genes responsive to abiotic stresses. These three linked genes from weedy rice were genetically dissected as single Mendelian factors in the same genetic background of cultivated rice to facilitate use in breeding new varieties resistant to PHS.
